Problem:
Consider the equation \\( u(z) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-zt} x(t) dt \\), which is a Laplace transform of a function \\( x(t) \\). Explore how modifying the original function \\( x(t) \\) affects the transform, and consider the impacts of two types of modifications: multiplication by a scalar function \\( h(t) \\) and addition of another function \\( w(t) \\).

If an external function \\( w(t) \\) is added to \\( x(t) \\) at a specific time to modify it into \\( y(t) = x(t) + w(t) \\), and this scenario is analyzed through its Laplace transform, does \\( u_y(z) \\) (the transform of \\( y(t) \\)) equal the sum of the transforms of \\( x(t) \\) and \\( w(t) \\) (i.e., \\( u_x(z) + u_w(z) \\))?
Explanation: The linearity property of the Laplace transform implies that the transform of a sum is the sum of the transforms. Therefore, the modification of \\( x(t) \\) by adding \\( w(t) \\) results in a transform that is exactly the sum of their individual transforms.
